body_html: It seems to me that you are trying to create an eval graph from your training graph. Since your graph contains a lot of things that are different between training and eval (i.e. batchnorm, dropout), you should create two separates graphs, either in two files or graph construction code that has a eval vs training parameter. One file creates the training graph and calls tf.contrib.quantize.create_training_graph() and the other creates the eval graph, restores the values from training, and calls tf.contrib.quantize.create_eval_graph().
body_text: It seems to me that you are trying to create an eval graph from your training graph. Since your graph contains a lot of things that are different between training and eval (i.e. batchnorm, dropout), you should create two separates graphs, either in two files or graph construction code that has a eval vs training parameter. One file creates the training graph and calls tf.contrib.quantize.create_training_graph() and the other creates the eval graph, restores the values from training, and calls tf.contrib.quantize.create_eval_graph().
body: It seems to me that you are trying to create an eval graph from your training graph. Since your graph contains a lot of things that are different between training and eval (i.e. batchnorm, dropout), you should create two separates graphs, either in two files or graph construction code that has a eval vs training parameter. One file creates the training graph and calls `tf.contrib.quantize.create_training_graph()` and the other creates the eval graph, restores the values from training, and calls `tf.contrib.quantize.create_eval_graph()`.
